arm_group.description: Rectal cancer participants who have not yet had surgery for rectal cancer or had surgery up to 2 years ago.

brief_summary.textblock:
The goal of this study is to learn about quality of life in patients who have or have had
      rectal cancer.

clinical_study.brief_title: Quality of Life (QOL) Following Surgical Treatment for Rectal Cancer

detailed_description.textblock:
You may be eligible to take part in this study if you have not yet had surgery for rectal
      cancer or if you had surgery up to 2 years ago.

      If you choose to take part in this study, you will complete 7 questionnaires about your
      quality of life. You will complete the questionnaires before surgery for rectal cancer (if
      you have not yet had surgery), at 6 and 12 months after surgery, and then 2, 3, 4 and 5
      years after surgery.  You will receive and return the questionnaires in the clinic, although
      if you are unable to come to the clinic for your regular follow-up, you may be able to
      receive and return your surveys by mail if recommended by the PI. They should take about
      20-30 minutes to complete.

      In addition, your medical records will be reviewed to learn about what kind of treatments
      you may have had, and whether you have had any complications related to your treatment.

      This is an investigational study.

      Up to 330 participants will be enrolled on this study. All will be enrolled at MD Anderson.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          1. Patient has histologically proven adenocarcinoma of the rectum (stage I - IV) that is
             planned to be treated by surgical resection performed with curative intent, or who
             has already received surgical treatment.

          2. Patient is aged 18 and older.

          3. Patient must sign an approved informed consent document and have the literary and
             physical ability to complete the questionnaire in English.

        Exclusion Criteria:

          1. Patient has been treated with pelvic radiation therapy for a diagnosis other than
             rectal cancer

          2. Patient has a concurrent cancer diagnosis at the time of consent

          3. Patient has recurrent disease.

study_pop.textblock: Rectal cancer participants at UT MD Anderson Cancer Center in Houston, Texas

intervention.description: 6 questionnaires completed regarding participant's quality of life. Questionnaires completed before surgery for rectal cancer, at 6 and 12 months after surgery, and then 2, 3, 4 and 5 years after surgery.

link.description: University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center Website

facility.name: University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center

clinical_study.official_title: Prospective Evaluation of Quality of Life and Utilities Following Surgical Treatment of Rectal Cancer

primary_outcome.description: Primary endpoint of study is the health state utilities at 24 months post-surgery. A health state utility is the degree of preference that individuals or society has for a particular health state or condition.  It ranges from 0 (death) to 1.0 (perfect health. The health state utilities are measured by EQ-5D. A summary index score can be derived from the questionnaires.
primary_outcome.measure: Health state Utilities Among Patients with Rectal Cancer

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Cohort, Time Perspective: Prospective
